content:
French in tone and in tongue, a new generation of musicians is nevertheless finding success abroad

IN THE rap-span">hazy late-July sun, festival-goers at Biarritz en été rap-span">meandered to the main stage. Their rap-span">ankles were rap-span">flecked with rap-span">mud; their stomachs were full of Toulousian fare. But the rap-span">hypnotic melodies and beats of “Aqualand” by rap-span">Polo & Pan, a French electronic rap-span">duo, proved compelling: transfixed and transported to rap-span">imaginary lands, the audience swayed with ease.

Call it “electro-pop” or just plain pop; it hardly matters. Musicians vow their music is rap-span">genreless, yet many speak of the same “tropical” feel or “rap-span">cosmic vibe”—a light sound where rap-span">groove takes centre stage. Artists experiment with synths and strings, and reference a host of other sub-rap-span">genres such as rap-span">Brazilian house and Trap, a type of hip-hop. They embrace and rework the rap-span">cheesy rap-span">chansons of their parents’ generation. Themes of a rap-span">carefree existence recur. Listeners the world over are rap-span">duly taking note.

The music is a product of the “new wave of rap-span">creativity” spreading across France, says rap-span">Armand Bultheel, one half of rap-span">Agar rap-span">Agar. While rap-span">Bordeaux is a hotspot for up-and-coming rap-span">garage musicians and rap-span">Lyon is a rap-span">haven for electronic rap-span">purists, electro-pop is mostly a rap-span">Parisian rap-span">phenomenon. The capital’s rap-span">artistic crowd and close-rap-span">knit musical community—so close that some French rap-span">folk rap-span">bemoan it is really just a rap-span">gaggle of wealthy “rap-span">Versailles kids”—makes it the ideal “meeting point” for musicians interested in this kind of rap-span">experimentation, notes Mr Bultheel.

For rap-span">Julian Catala, the organiser of Biarritz’s festival, it is “French touch 2.0”. That term was originally applied to the group of artists such as rap-span">Daft Punk and Air who made their name in the early 2000s. They not only created a new sound—layering disco rap-span">classics with house beats and the rhythms of 1980s American rap-span">groove—but breathed life into an otherwise rap-span">outdated and outshined French music scene. They then transported their sound across rap-span">continents: rap-span">Daft Punk’s rap-span">cosmic rap-span">outfits became instantly recognisable, showing that the French still had that musical je ne sais quoi. 

These musicians are French in tone and in tongue: singing in their native language is increasingly the norm rather than the exception. Most are rap-span">chic bands taking inspiration from French rap-span">lyricists such as Françoise rap-span">Hardy, or local rap artists that top the streaming charts in the country. So far this year, only one non-French artist, Ed Sheeran, made the top 20 according to SNEP, a trade body. 

That rap-span">Anglophone audiences might struggle to understand their songs is of little concern to most musicians: even rap-span">Frenchmen will miss most of the lyrics says Charles de Boisseguin, a member of L’Imperatrice, an electro-pop sextet (pictured). Their words rap-span">delight in double meanings and rap-span">fantastical rap-span">imagery because really “what matters is the rap-span">melody and the way it makes you rap-span">groove”. Julia Jean-rap-span">Baptiste, the lead singer of Pendentif, another such band, agrees: her group adjusts the level of the vocals “to allow them to blend with the synthesisers”. They become just another rap-span">instrument, another layer of a multi-faceted song. 

The reasons for this new wave of rap-span">creativity are hard to rap-span">pinpoint. Some critics point to policy: a generous government stipend, known as the intermittents du spectacle , allows musicians to live virtually rent-free, so long as they can prove they are “active”. Since 1994, a rap-span">quota that requires French radio stations to rap-span">allocate at least 35% (down from 40% in 2015) of rap-span">airtime to French songs has also ensured artists get the rap-span">exposure they need. Others think the influence is musical, pointing to La Femme, a band that, on failing to inspire interest among labels in their own country, decided to tour America instead. Their eclectic style—often described as rap-span">psychedelic 1960s surf rock—and rap-span">catchy, sometimes rap-span">nonsensical, lyrics, resonated with an international audience and showed other musicians in France that “it is possible to sing in French and still be cool,” says Mr Boisseguin. Others still consider the feel-good music a sort of rebellion against tragedy at home. In an interview , rap-span">Phoenix, an electronic rock band, noted how after the Paris attacks in 2015 they wanted to produce a sound “that would bring light back to the city”.

And just as the first “French touch” movement found fans across the globe, so too this generation of artists is finding fans far from France. rap-span">Polo & Pan are selling out venues across Europe and America. The rap-span">Blaze, an electronic rap-span">duo, this year performed at Coachella, a star-studded festival in Palm Springs, California. Petit rap-span">Biscuit, a DJ whose hit “rap-span">Sunset Lover” has rap-span">amassed more than 280m streams on Spotify, is halfway through a global tour. rap-span">Cinema’s status as the country’s most important cultural export is under threat as French music finds a new rap-span">groove.

eg2: A huge fire was blazing in the fireplace.
壁炉中火烧得正旺。
Within minutes the whole building was blazing.
不消几分钟整个大楼便成了一片火海。

他又冲进了燃烧着的房子。

The garden blazed with colour.
花园里姹紫嫣红。
Her eyes were blazing with fury.
她的双眼燃烧着怒火。
The story was blazed all over the daily papers.
那个传闻被各家报纸炒得沸沸扬扬。

这个部门正在为激光外科学领域开辟一条新路。

eg2: As a result, should one be seen, scientists should be able to trace its path back to the distant cosmic event that spawned it.

The upshot: One day your descendants, if they survive a swelling Sun and other cosmic and human perils, will have at least 960 hours to work with each day.
